author: ABQnews Staff
title: Surveys to focus on health care
text:
Two health groups in the state have joined forces to survey New Mexico residents about their experiences with the federal health-care act.
The survey, at conalma.org/2015-aca-survey/, is conducted by Con Alma Health Foundation, which seeks to improve health care in the state, and the Alliance of Health Councils, comprised of county-level councils.
The survey asks basic questions such as where the person obtained health-care insurance, whether enough information was provided and whether there were a sufficient number of plans from which to choose.
There’s also a place to rank how positive or negative the experience of signing up was, as well as open-ended questions on how the Affordable Care Act has affected the respondent’s family and what improvements can be made.
The point of the questionnaire is to “understand how the Affordable Care Act is impacting individuals,” said Amy Duggan, a member of Con Alma’s community advisory council. The deadline for submitting it is Nov. 2.
The survey is part of a broader effort by Con Alma, which also has a research team conducting interviews and looking at “secondary data,” such as reports and other information, Duggan said.
Meanwhile, the New Mexico Health Exchange, which oversees the state’s health insurance marketplace, will commission a separate survey to find out what motivates people to buy insurance. Results will be used to tailor the way it reaches out to urban and rural residents, including tribal members living on reservations.
